message: Senator Grassley's Veterans Fellow, Dave Allen, presented Vietnam War veteran Steve Kellerhals with service medals he earned. The presentation occurred at Mr. Kellerhals’ home in Altoona.   The medals include the Bronze Star, two Purple Hearts, Air Medal, National Defense Service Medal, Vietnam Service Medal, Combat Infantryman Badge 1st Award, Republic of Vietnam Campaign Ribbon with device (1960), Expert Badge and Rifle Bar, Marksman Badge and Auto Rifle Bar and Machine Gun Bar and the 50th Anniversary Vietnam Commemorative Lapel Pin.   Senator Grassley is glad to help veterans obtain the medals they earned. A list of his offices to contact is available at http://www.grassley.senate.gov/explore/regional-offices

Senator Grassley welcomed new members of the Senate Judiciary Committee for the 115th Congress.   “The Judiciary Committee handles a broad policy jurisdiction and oversight portfolio, as well as processing appointments to the administration and federal judiciary, which are all important responsibilities that the committee takes very seriously,” Chairman Grassley and Ranking Member Feinstein said. “We welcome all of the new and returning members of the Judiciary Committee and look forward to having a productive two years.”

A new Associated Press report shows that a Mexican national, Tomas Martinez-Maldonado, accused of raping a 13-year-old girl, was deported ten times and was voluntarily removed from the United States another nine times since 2003. Senator Grassley, Chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, had written in early December a letter to Department of Homeland Security Secretary Jeh Johnson questioning how the man was able to re-enter so many times and remain in the country.  “This is an extremely disturbing case,” Chairman Grassley wrote. “In order for Congress to better understand the circumstances that led to this alleged rape of a child, we request information about Martinez-Maldonado’s criminal and immigration history, and why he was able to enter and remain in the country despite his unlawful status.”  Senator Grassley’s full letter can be found here: http://www.grassley.senate.gov/news/news-releases/sens-grassley-moran-roberts-press-obama-administration-answers-criminal-immigrant

Senator Grassley was sworn in today for a new term serving Iowa in the United States Senate. Vice President Biden administered the oath of office.   “I do solemnly swear that I will support and defend the Constitution of the United States against all enemies, foreign and domestic; that I will bear true faith and allegiance to the same; that I take this obligation freely, without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion; and that I will well and faithfully discharge the duties of the office on which I am about to enter: So help me God.”   Senator Grassley will continue to serve on the Senate Judiciary, Finance, Agriculture and Budget committees. He is also expected to retain his position as Chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee.

Senator Grassley met with Dr. Ben Carson, President-elect Donald J. Trump's nominee to lead the Department of Housing and Urban Development. Senator Grassley discussed his long record of seeking accountability from the agency and public housing authorities in fulfilling their responsibilities.  “The taxpayers spend billions of dollars a year to provide safe, affordable housing for those in need. HUD is good at writing checks but not as interested in making sure the money is spent as intended,” Senator Grassley said. “Several public housing authorities around the country have used the lack of checks and balances to run up excessive executive salaries, travel expenses and other wasteful spending…I conveyed to Dr. Carson the problems I’ve run into and how I hope for more accountability and transparency for how taxpayer dollars are used to fulfill housing needs under a new administration…I look forward to Dr. Carson’s swift confirmation so he can get to work making much-needed changes at HUD.”

Last Congress, Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley led the effort to reform the criminal justice system.  Senator Grassley led a bill through the Judiciary Committee that would recalibrate prison sentences for certain drug offenders, target violent criminals and grant judges greater discretion at sentencing for lower-level drug crimes. It also seeks to curb recidivism by helping prisoners successfully re-enter society.   As a new Congress begins, Senator Grassley plans to continue to press for commonsense reforms to the criminal justice system that prevent taxpayer dollars from being wasted and improve public safety.

Senator Grassley and Senator Joni Ernst, along with Senator Deb Fischer and Senator Ben Sasse from Nebraska, re-introduced Sarah's Law, legislation to honor Sarah Root, an Iowan from Council Bluffs who was killed nearly one year ago by Edwin Mejia, a drunk driver in the country illegally. First introduced last year, Sarah's Law would amend the immigration laws to ensure that illegal immigrants who are a threat to public safety are taken into custody and off the streets. Mejia remains at large, continuing to deprive the Root family of the justice and closure they deserve. Under this law, Mejia would have been detained, rather than allowed to flee from justice and the Root family would be kept up-to-date on Mejia’s status as well as federal immigration authorities’ efforts to remove him from the United States.  “No family should be forced to endure the pain that the Roots have felt since last year,” Senator Grassley said. “First, young Sarah’s life was cut short by an immigrant who disregarded the rule of law and decided to get behind the wheel after drinking. Then the Obama Administration refused to take custody of Sarah’s killer because it didn’t consider him a priority, allowing him to disappear into the shadows. The Roots have been robbed of their daughter, and at least for now, they have been robbed of justice. Our legislation, named in Sarah’s memory, will ensure that those who harm or kill Americans will be taken into custody and removed while also ensuring that victims and their families get the information they deserve from the government as they pursue justice.”

Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley met with law enforcement personnel from across the country who support the nomination of Senator Jeff Sessions to be the next Attorney General.   “Law enforcement personnel know, like those of us who have served with him in the Senate, that Senator Sessions is an honorable man, and they have good reason to support his nomination to be Attorney General," Senator Grassley said. "I was glad to meet with them and hear their thoughts on the nomination and other legislation that may come before the Judiciary Committee.”

Senator Grassley led a meeting of Midwestern senators with President-elect Donald J. Trump's nominee to lead the Environmental Protection Agency, Oklahoma Attorney General Scott Pruitt. Senator Grassley organized the meeting because he wanted to convey the importance of biofuels to job creation, energy security, the environment and meeting the country’s significant energy needs. Senator Grassley has been disappointed by the Obama Administration’s lack of strong support in implementing the congressionally-mandated Renewable Fuel Standard (RFS).  “We got a very positive response on Mr. Pruitt’s support not just for the RFS but more importantly, for the rule of law,” Senator Grassley said. “The rule of law is that what Congress passed, the EPA is supposed to follow and not undermine it, the way the current administration has done with the RFS. The purpose of the meeting was to convey the contributions that Iowa and other renewable energy-producing states contribute to the economy and otherwise. From the standpoint of what President-elect Trump wants to accomplish, renewable energy supports a high number of jobs, 43,000 jobs in Iowa just with biofuels and another 7,000 jobs in wind energy. We have to import less oil from the Mideast because we have a very vibrant ethanol industry. As far as whether I’ll support the nomination, I tend to wait for nomination hearings before making up my mind. We got a positive comment that the law’s going to be followed, and that’s very, very important.”

As a new Congress begins, Senator Grassley is continuing to press the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) for answers on whether it sought to recoup tax dollars overpaid for EpiPens from drug maker Mylan and added a new request for two additional drugs reportedly misclassified under the Medicaid Drug Rebate Program, Dilaudid and Prilosec.   “Congress and the American public have a right to know what additional steps, if any, CMS took to hold Mylan and other companies accountable and CMS has an obligation to answer,” Senator Grassley said. “These misclassifications could have cost the taxpayers and states hundreds of millions of dollars. The Obama Administration’s silence on these issues is unwarranted and irresponsible.”

This week, Senator Grassley led a meeting of Midwestern senators with President-elect Donald J. Trump’s nominee to lead the Environmental Protection Agency, Oklahoma Attorney General Scott Pruitt. In his weekly Q&A, Senator Grassley discusses his meeting with Attorney General Pruitt, his expectation that the incoming administration will enforce the congressionally-mandated Renewable Fuel Standard and the significant role biofuels and other forms of clean energy play in ensuring the nation’s energy independence, a better environment and good-paying jobs right here in America.   “When it comes to protecting clean energy, a public policy I’ve worked to secure and strengthen throughout my public service, I will trust but verify the Trump administration’s commitment to the RFS and other renewable energy sources across-the-board," Senator Grassley said. "Throughout the 115th Congress, I will continue to conduct robust oversight of the EPA and its implementation of the RFS as Congress intended. What’s more, I will work to advance clean energy policies, incentives and infrastructure that help clean our air and build better, safer, stronger, more prosperous communities and livelihoods.”

Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley opened hearings to consider President-elect Donald J. Trump's nomination of Senator Jeff Sessions to lead the Department of Justice as Attorney General.  Speaking on Senator Sessions' nomination, Chairman Grassley said, “We know him well. We know the policy positions he has taken as a legislator. I’ve been on both sides of debates with Senator Sessions. Having served with him for so long we pretty well know whether he supports your policy positions or opposes them. He tells us so with thoughtfulness, humility and respect. As a former Chairman of this Committee has put it, Senator Sessions is ‘wonderful to work with.’ We know him to be, as another senior Democrat on this Committee described him, ‘a man of his word.’ As a third senior Democrat colleague put it, ‘he is always a gentleman’; ‘he is straightforward and fair.’ Most of all, the Members of this Committee know him to be a leader who has served the people of Alabama—and all Americans—with integrity, dedication, and courage.‎”  Read Chairman Grassley’s full speech here: www.grassley.senate.gov/news/news-releases/grassley-statement-nominations-hearing-jeff-sessions-be-us-attorney-general

Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley questioned President-elect Donald J. Trump's Attorney General nominee Senator Jeff Sessions on the current Administration's enforcement policies that negatively impact American workers and how he would investigate abuses of the law.  “Senator Sessions, you’ve been a vocal champion for American workers, especially as we have heard so much about how American workers are being laid off and replaced by cheaper, foreign labor imported through some of our visa programs,” Chairman Grassley said. “The Obama administration has failed to protect American workers here…will you be more aggressive in investigating the abuses of these visa programs?”  Watch Attorney General nominee Jeff Sessions’ answer below.

“Almost three years after long waits for medical appointments for veterans exploded into a nationwide scandal, the Phoenix VA hospital at the center of the crisis still is not providing timely care,” the Washington Post reports, citing a watchdog group responsible for investigating whistleblowers’ claims.   As part of his oversight of the Department of Veterans Affairs, Senator Grassley has been monitoring the situation at the Phoenix VA and has been in frequent contact with whistleblowers. Unfortunately, whistleblowers often face backlash, sometimes illegally, for exposing embarrassing problems in government.  “Sometimes whistleblowers expose matters of life and death, other times they expose harm against the taxpayers, and sometimes they expose all of the above,” Senator Grassley said. “When care is delayed or mishandled, veterans suffer, and the taxpayers are shortchanged…I look forward to continued justice for whistleblowers and the public they serve. I urge the VA leadership to ensure that all whistleblowers are treated fairly under the law.”

In 1986, Senator Chuck Grassley led the False Claims Act to passage, a law that allows for the prosecution of fraud against taxpayers by companies and government contractors. Senator Grassley’s law is credited with helping the federal government recover more than $4.7 billion from fraudsters last year alone, and more than $53.1 billion total since its enactment.  Leading the Senate Judiciary Committee hearing to consider Senator Jeff Sessions for Attorney General, Chairman Grassley asked, “If you're confirmed, will you pledge to vigorously enforce the False Claims Act and devote adequate resources to investigating and prosecuting False Claims Act cases?”  Watch Attorney General nominee Sessions’ answer below, as well as his thoughts on the importance of whistleblowers in government.

As Chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, Senator Grassley led a hearing for the nominee to be the next Attorney General, Senator Jeff Sessions. The committee had nearly 11 hours of Q&A with Senator Sessions on Tuesday, and on Wednesday had another four hours of questions with outside witnesses. The hearing made it clear that Senator Sessions is very well qualified for the position, he will be an independent Attorney General and he will enforce the law.   Listen to what Senator Grassley had to say about it.

Senator Grassley met with General John Kelly, President-elect Donald J. Trump's nominee to be Secretary of Homeland Security. The Senate Judiciary Committee, which Senator Grassley leads, has legislative and oversight jurisdiction over federal immigration law, which mainly falls under Homeland Security's enforcement authority.   “I appreciate General Kelly meeting with me,” Senator Grassley said. “It was clear from our conversation that he understands the critical importance border security plays in our overall homeland security, especially with respect to the flow of illegal immigration and dangerous narcotics across the border into our country.”  “We also discussed a lot of issues surrounding the flawed immigration enforcement policies that are currently being employed and how the incoming administration can help ensure that criminal immigrants are not released onto the streets of American communities and are deported. I mentioned the case involving Sarah Root, and the need to do more to get drunk drivers who are here illegally off our streets.”  Senator Grassley and General Kelly also discussed the importance of reforming federal visa programs to prevent fraud so that foreign workers don’t displace American workers.

A new government report, commissioned by the Department of Agriculture, finds that corn ethanol is even better for the environment than previously thought. According to the study, biofuels reduce greenhouse gases by 43% relative to gasoline, more than twice as much as previous estimates from the Environmental Protection Agency.    “That marks a potential blow to critics who have questioned whether ethanol, the foundation of the country’s biofuels program, is better for the environment than petroleum-based fuels,” said the Cedar Rapids Gazette.    “Over the years, I’ve worked tirelessly to debunk the many myths about corn ethanol,” Senator Grassley said. “One such myth is that conventional ethanol is no cleaner than gasoline. This report completely and definitively settles the debate regarding the positive environmental benefits of conventional corn ethanol.”

In his weekly Q&A, Senator Grassley discusses legislation he is supporting aimed at countering overly burdensome and costly regulations by reasserting congressional authority over lawmaking that has been slowly ceded to executive branch agencies over the years, undermining the intent of the U.S. Constitution, which created three co-equal branches of government.   “Consider that during President Obama’s first seven years in office, his administration adopted at least 230 major regulations,” Senator Grassley said. “This regulatory burden imposed $108 billion in new costs to the U.S. economy. This cloak of rules and regulations is a stealth tax on American consumers and workers who ultimately pay for its enforcement and compliance costs.”

Awards for IRS whistleblowers were up 322% last year, and that’s good news for taxpayers.   “In 2016, the Whistleblower Office made 418 awards, totaling about $61 million,” reported Forbes. “That was a 322 percent increase over the 99 awards paid in 2015. The number of claims were up too, about 6.4 percent since 2015. And case closures of whistleblower cases went up 99 percent.”    Senator Grassley wrote the 2006 provisions improving the incentives for whistleblowers to come forward about large dollar tax fraud. Since 2007, whistleblowers have helped the IRS to collect $3.4 billion that otherwise would have been lost to fraud. “Cracking down on big-dollar tax fraud is a matter of fairness to the vast majority of taxpayers who pay what they owe,” Senator Grassley said.

Senator Grassley led a meeting of several fellow senators from Midwestern biofuels-producing states with former Texas Governor Rick Perry, President-elect Donald J. Trump's nominee to serve as Secretary of the Department of Energy, which conducts research important to energy policymaking.  “I was looking for assurance that Governor Perry appreciates the role of biofuels in an all-of-the-above energy strategy to meet the country’s needs,” Senator Grassley said. “I received that assurance and also the message that Governor Perry will carry out the direction of the incoming president, who has said he supports biofuels. This is the second major Trump nominee, the first being EPA administrator nominee Scott Pruitt, to express the sentiment that the executive branch will follow the rule of law and stay the course on biofuels. That message is important to continue the tremendous benefits of biofuels in job creation, economic investment, fuel independence and environmental benefits.”

Senator Grassley met with Robert Lighthizer, President-elect Donald Trump’s nominee to serve as U.S. Trade Representative, an agency tasked with negotiating trade deals on behalf of the United States.  “The main point I wanted to convey is that regardless of what action the incoming President takes on trade, he and his advisers should consider the effects on agriculture,” Senator Grassley said. “Iowa is an exporting state, with a tremendous amount of agricultural commodities and other goods shipped to markets around the world…I expect the new administration to work hard to maintain existing markets for Iowa and other farm states’ exports and open new markets as well.”  The Senate Finance Committee, where Senator Grassley is a senior member and former chairman, will handle the nomination.

Senator Grassley, author of laws protecting whistleblowers and encouraging them to come forward about large dollar tax fraud, received a commitment to support whistleblower functions from Treasury secretary nominee Steven Mnuchin at a hearing on his nomination.   “Having a Treasury secretary who understands the whistleblower role in enforcing tax fraud is important,” Senator Grassley said. “Whistleblowers have helped the IRS recover $3.4 billion that otherwise would have been lost to fraud. Cracking down on big dollar tax fraud is a matter of fairness to the vast majority of taxpayers who pay what they owe. The IRS has made progress in working with whistleblowers, but there’s more work to be done. Mr. Mnuchin gave his assurance that he’ll work with me if confirmed to support tax fraud whistleblowers.”

Senator Grassley met with Iowans in Washington celebrating the nation’s longstanding tradition of the peaceful transfer of power. Senator Grassley looks forward to working with his colleagues in Congress and the new administration in 2017.

“Today, Americans had the opportunity to witness a hallmark of American democracy in the peaceful transfer of power from one president to the next," Senator Grassley said. "Nobody should be surprised at the priorities laid out in President Donald J. Trump’s speech. It focused on the same ideals that got him elected. President Trump has given hope to many Americans who have long felt forgotten. He is empowering Americans and inspiring people to believe that government can work for them again. I appreciate President Trump’s pledge to create jobs, help struggling families, secure our borders, combat radical Islamic terrorism and resume America’s position of leadership in the free world. President Trump outlined a bold agenda to put America first, and now it’s time for Congress to get to work. As the President said, ‘No challenge can match the heart and fight and spirit of America.’”

The vast majority of taxpayers pay their obligations due on time and in full, but tax evasion, underpayment and avoidance continue to grow.   In his weekly Q&A, Senator Grassley explains the importance of the IRS Whistleblower Office and why in some instances he supports private debt collection for unpaid taxes.   “The IRS needs to leverage our anti-fraud tools for public benefit so that hard-working taxpayers who play by the rules and pay their share aren’t penalized for their honesty,” Senator Grassley said. Read more by clicking below.

Senator Grassley introduced bipartisan legislation to overhaul the H-1B high-tech visa program. The bill would help root out fraud and abuse by some companies that employ cheaper foreign labor at the expense of American workers.   “Congress created these programs to complement America’s high-skilled workforce, not replace it,” Senator Grassley said. “Unfortunately, some companies are trying to exploit the programs by cutting American workers for cheaper labor. We need programs dedicated to putting American workers first.”   Learn more about Senator Grassley's legislation here: www.grassley.senate.gov/news/news-releases/grassley-durbin-introduce-reforms-skilled-non-immigrant-visa-programs

Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley reintroduced legislation to help businesses comply with immigration laws by requiring the use of E-Verify, an internet-based system that assists employers in checking the legal status of their workforce.  “Businesses across the country have opted to use the E-Verify system to help comply with our immigration laws,” Senator Grassley said. “E-Verify is a proven tool for employers, including myself, that helps reduce incentives for illegal immigration and safeguards job opportunities for Americans and other legal workers. Expanding the system to every workplace will improve accountability for all businesses and take an important step toward putting American workers first.”  Learn more about the “Accountability Through Electronic Verification Act” by clicking below.

Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Grassley, along with Ranking Member Feinstein and Senate Leaders McConnell and Schumer, met with President Donald J. Trump and Vice President Mike Pence to discuss the Supreme Court vacancy. Chairman Grassley shares his thoughts about the Oval Office meeting and what's ahead as the nomination process moves forward in a video address below.

The Ottumwa Courier praised Senator Grassley's bipartisan legislation to reform the H-1B federal immigration program so it is no longer exploited by some companies to hire foreign labor at the expense of American workers.  “This is an example of the kind of cooperation across party lines we should expect of our elected leaders,” the editorial board writes.   “We need programs dedicated to putting American workers first,” Senator Grassley said. Learn more about the legislation here: www.grassley.senate.gov/news/news-releases/grassley-durbin-introduce-reforms-skilled-non-immigrant-visa-programs

“We’ve seen the consequences of neglecting to enforce our immigration laws both at the border and in communities across the country,” Senator Grassley said following President Trump’s executive orders on immigration. “The tragic death of Sarah Root, one of my constituents, could have been avoided had the previous administration placed a higher priority on enforcing the laws on the books. No family should have to bury a child because the federal government refused to take the law seriously. President Trump’s executive orders are an important step toward securing the border, restoring the rule of law and strengthening public safety by ensuring that those who threaten the safety of our communities are no longer allowed to wreak continued havoc.”  Sarah Root of Council Bluffs was struck and killed by an undocumented immigrant who was drag racing while drunk. The immigrant, Edwin Mejia, had a prior history of skipping court-ordered meetings, but was not considered an enforcement priority by the Obama Administration. He was charged with felony motor vehicle homicide, but was released on bond and is now a fugitive from the law.

Senator Grassley re-introduced an amendment to the U.S. Constitution that would require Congress to balance its budget, which would help reverse decades of dangerous growth in the national debt, now at nearly $20 trillion. If the current national debt were divided equally among Americans, every Iowan would owe more than $61,000.  “It’s simple math: The federal government should not be spending more taxpayer money than it brings in,” Senator Grassley said. “Families, farmers and businesses across my home state of Iowa and across the entire country make difficult decisions every day to balance the books. It’s the responsible thing to do. Almost every state has adopted some form of a balanced budget requirement, and it’s past time that the federal government follows suit.”

Senator Grassley is an original cosponsor of reintroduced legislation to permanently repeal the federal estate tax, commonly known as the death tax, that can hurt family farms and businesses as the result of the owner's death.   “It’s getting harder all the time to have a family farm or family-run business,” Senator Grassley said. “Congress ought to do everything possible to encourage family enterprises to stay in operation and get next generations involved. The estate tax is counterproductive to jobs and economic growth. It just isn’t needed. I hope this is one of many tax burdens that will fall by the wayside through comprehensive tax reform or any other means that might be available.”  The bill is supported by farming, manufacturing, business, development and taxpayer groups across Iowa and the nation.

Senator Grassley continued with his annual #99CountyMeetings in Iowa this week, visiting Central City High School students and answering their questions about his work for Iowans.   “‘I love coming to schools because people don’t understand government very well,’ Grassley said when a girl in the front asked about his favorite activity,” reported the The Gazette.  Senator Grassley holds meetings in each of Iowa’s 99 counties at least once annually, holding Q&As in a variety of formats, including places of education, community centers, hospitals, factory floors, businesses and town halls.

“I’ve never thought about the issue of life as political or partisan, but about ensuring the most vulnerable among us, the unborn, are afforded the same dignity, compassion and right to life as all Americans,” Senator Chuck Grassley said following The March for Life today in Washington. “Advances in science have made ignoring the humanity of the unborn no longer tenable. I have been honored to serve on behalf of Iowa families in the United States Senate with a 100% pro-life record. As Americans of all stripes from across the country march today in Washington, I stand with them.” #MarchForLife

As a longtime advocate of fiscal responsibility, Senator Grassley is cosponsoring an amendment to the U.S. Constitution that would require Congress to balance its budget. As it stands, the federal government is nearly $20 trillion in debt, with debt expected to grow even faster over the next generation.   “Thomas Jefferson, one of the authors of the Declaration of Independence and U.S. president, wrote: ‘We must not let our rulers load us with perpetual debt.’ I agree,” Senator Grassley says in his weekly Q&A. “The federal government cannot tax, spend and borrow its way to prosperity. There is no better time for Congress to pass this amendment and get America’s fiscal house in order once and for all.”  Learn more about the federal government’s fiscal outlook, the Balanced Budget Amendment and Senator Grassley’s thoughts on the national debt by clicking below.

Chairman Chuck Grassley opened the Senate Judiciary Committee meeting on the nomination of Senator Jeff Sessions to be Attorney General of the United States by recounting the nominee’s commitment to the rule of law and his understanding of the clear difference between legislating and enforcing law.  “He explained that he’s enthusiastically prepared to set aside his role as legislator and adopt a new role as our chief law enforcement officer,” Chairman Grassley said. “And he told us he’ll execute that role with strength, integrity, and independence in order to provide equal justice for all...I am pleased to support his nomination and I’ll be pleased to cast my vote in favor of his confirmation. I urge my colleagues to do the same.”  Read Chairman Grassley's full statement here: http://www.grassley.senate.gov/news/news-releases/grassley-statement-judiciary-committee-meeting-sen-sessions-nomination-be

Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley made the following statement after President Donald J. Trump announced his intention to nominate Tenth Circuit Court of Appeals Judge Neil Gorsuch to be the next Associate Justice on the United States Supreme Court. The Senate Judiciary Committee has jurisdiction over the federal courts and will vet and conduct a hearing on the nominee.  “Judge Gorsuch is universally respected across the ideological spectrum as a mainstream judge who applies the law without regard to person or his own preferences. By all accounts, he has a record of deciding cases based on the text of the Constitution and the law. That’s important because in our system of government, Congress, not judges, make the laws. I look forward to continuing to review his qualifications and to hearing from Judge Gorsuch himself about his approach to the law.  “Following the death of Justice Scalia as Americans were beginning to cast their votes for the next President, I said that we’d move forward with the next President’s nomination to the Supreme Court, regardless of who won. The President has made his selection and that’s what we’ll do.”  Gorsuch was confirmed to the circuit court by unanimous voice vote in 2006 with the bipartisan support of his home state senators Wayne Allard and Ken Salazar. There are 31 sitting senators who were in the Senate at the time of the unanimous confirmation vote, including 11 Democrats. Prior to being a circuit court judge, he practiced law, clerked for two Supreme Court Justices, and earned a doctorate degree in legal philosophy from Oxford.

Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley joined Fox News' Bret Baier on Special Report to discuss Supreme Court nominee Neil Gorsuch and what he expects in the coming weeks ahead of confirmation hearings.  "What even Democrats have said about him, who know him, he's an eminently fair and qualified person," Chairman Grassley said.

Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley spoke with Fox News’ Bill Hemmer on America’s Newsroom about President Trump’s cabinet and Supreme Court nominees and the confirmation process in the Senate. Senator Grassley also spoke about Iowans' concerns he hears at his #99CountyMeetings.

Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley met with President Trump’s Supreme Court nominee Judge Neil Gorsuch to discuss his judicial record and philosophy. Judge Gorsuch is exceptionally well-qualified and has a reputation for applying the Constitution and the laws as they are written.

As the new Congress and White House begin work on a legislative agenda for 2017, tax reform remains a top priority for Senator Grassley.   “If there’s one issue that unites Americans, it is the need to simplify the nation’s tax laws,” Senator Grassley said. “Any blueprint for comprehensive tax reform needs to prioritize fairness, simplification, U.S. jobs and economic growth.”  Learn more about what reforms to the nation’s tax code Senator Grassley is advocating for in his weekly Q&A below.

Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley wrote to President Trump's Secretary of State, Rex Tillerson, with the same request to declassify the details of the Australia refugee deal he made of the Obama Administration.   “As I said before, the American people have a right to be fully aware of the actions of their government regarding foreign nationals who may be admitted to the United States,” Chairman Grassley wrote. “American taxpayers not only foot the bill for the majority of the refugee resettlement in the United States, but they bear any consequences regarding the security implications of those admitted to our country.”   Read Chairman Grassley’s full letter to Secretary Tillerson here: http://www.grassley.senate.gov/news/news-releases/grassley-renews-call-declassification-covert-australia-refugee-deal

As an equal opportunity overseer, Senator Grassley conducts oversight of both Republican and Democratic Administrations with equal fervor. He has advised the new administration about how helpful whistleblowers can be in exposing waste, fraud and abuse in the federal government.   “Grassley has long been a stickler when it comes to congressional oversight, regardless of which gavel he has held, especially on the matter of protecting executive-branch whistleblowers from intimidation and retribution,” Roll Call wrote.  Senator Grassley is a longtime champion of whistleblower rights, and as Chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, has broad oversight jurisdiction over several federal departments and agencies.

Senator Grassley's Veterans Fellow based in Des Moines, Dave Allen, presented Vietnam War veteran Dave Kellenberger of Norwalk with a 50th anniversary lapel pin commemorating his service during the war. Dave’s wife, Jennifer, was also in attendance.  Senator Grassley is glad to help veterans obtain the medals they earned. A list of his offices to contact is available at http://www.grassley.senate.gov/explore/regional-offices

Senator Grassley's offices in Iowa and in Washington are receiving an increased volume of calls from Iowans and from across the country. Unfortunately, not all callers are able to speak with Senator Grassley's staff right away. Senator Grassley wants to hear Iowans' views on issues and help them cut through the bureaucratic red tape.   Iowans who need help on casework and cannot get through on the phone should contact Senator Grassley’s office online at the links below or try calling back later. From helping veterans navigate the VA to ensuring that seniors and those with disabilities receive their Social Security and Medicare benefits, Senator Grassley works to assist Iowans who are having trouble navigating the federal bureaucracy.  For assistance in dealing with federal agencies, click here: https://www.grassley.senate.gov/constituents/help-with-federal-agencies  To express an opinion or ask a question about Senator Grassley’s work, click here: https://www.grassley.senate.gov/constituents/questions-and-comments   For further contact information and for a list of all six of Senator Grassley’s offices in Iowa, click here: http://www.grassley.senate.gov/contact

The United States Mint will begin the launch of a new quarter honoring Iowa’s Effigy Mounds National Monument today at a ceremony at Waukon High School.   “Effigy Mounds may not be as well-known nationally as many of the more famous units of the National Park System,” Senator Grassley said. “The national exposure that this new quarter will provide will help many more Americans discover the fascinating history and natural beauty of Effigy Mounds National Monument. I’ve been to the park myself and encourage Iowans and others to visit.”  This initiative will encourage tourism to the area, helping the local economies of northeast Iowa, and will shine a spotlight on one of Iowa's most unique attractions.   For more information on the park and for help in planning a visit, click here: https://www.nps.gov/efmo/index.htm

Last night, Senator Grassley attended President Donald J. Trump’s first joint session of Congress.    “President Trump delivered an assessment of the challenges we face as a country, but he also outlined a call to action for Congress and the White House to work to address those many challenges,” Senator Grassley said following the address.     “I appreciated the President’s emphasis on curbing harmful government regulations that are not only counterproductive but too often stifle the full potential of the American worker, farmer and entrepreneur. The Environmental Protection Agency’s poorly conceived ‘Waters of the U.S.’ rule is only one of many such regulations that do little to serve the interests of Iowans and pose a serious threat to local economies.    “I was glad to hear the President state his desire to work with Congress on a comprehensive overhaul of the federal tax code, which is outdated, and should be made fairer and simpler. Boosting domestic manufacturing should be a priority, as well as maintaining the integrity of existing laws meant to encourage the use of clean energy, such as the Renewable Fuel Standard. Renewable energy employs tens of thousands of Iowans and many others around the country. That ought to stay as it is and even improve.    “Like the tax code, any renegotiation of international trade deals must consider the agricultural sector of the American economy, which accounts for one in five jobs in Iowa and is the backbone of the rural economy.    “I welcome the President’s pledge to keep his commitment to work to repeal and replace Obamacare with a plan that increases access to quality health care and lowers costs for American families. Far too many Iowans face skyrocketing premiums, making quality health care unaffordable for them as this broken law continues to collapse. And the Administration and Congress should act to bring down the high prices of prescription drugs.    “I’m also glad the President kept his pledge to nominate a Supreme Court justice who is committed to interpreting law not making law, helping to safeguard our system of government with its three co-equal branches providing checks and balances on one another.    “I was heartened to hear the President reiterate his promise to protect our nation’s borders and enforce federal immigration laws to ensure that dangerous criminal illegal immigrants aren’t let loose on American streets. He’s also making sure that the victims and the families of victims of criminal illegal immigrants will not be forgotten. I look forward to working with the President to put in place policies that help the American people succeed and prosper.”

Her ability to continue in her job as Attorney General depended on a Clinton victory in the election.  “And she had a private meeting with President Bill Clinton on her government airplane while the Department was investigating Secretary Clinton.  “Where were the calls from Democratic Leadership for a special counsel then? Where were these calls for a special counsel when Congress referred a criminal contempt citation to the Department of Justice against Attorney General Holder for withholding documents in the Fast and Furious scandal?  “He misled Congress about when he learned about Fast and Furious. Where were the calls from the other side to have hearings on that?”  “More importantly, any insinuation that Mr. Rosenstein lacks the impartiality or professionalism necessary to handle these matters is out of line. His independence is beyond reproach.”  Read Chairman Grassley’s full opening statement and introduction of Iowan Rachel Brand here: http://www.grassley.senate.gov/news/news-releases/grassley-deputy-attorney-general-nomination-hearing-any-talk-special-counsel

"Civil asset forfeiture laws empower the government to seize property linked to prohibited behavior and criminal enterprise," Senator Grassley said in his weekly Q&A. "Seizing ill-gotten financial assets enables law enforcement to put the brakes on criminal profits that underwrite crime and violence in society. Drying up this funding stream helps save lives and protect public safety."  "In recent years, however, legitimate constitutional concerns call into question the misuse of forfeiture programs across the country. Changes to the program now allow law enforcement agencies and the IRS to keep proceeds from seized assets. This arguably has created a perverse incentive, expanding the program’s intent from a tool to seize criminal assets to stop crime to a tool that generates resources to flow into forfeiture funds. Previously, seized assets were deposited into the general treasury. Now law enforcement agencies may be enticed to seize private property, cash and vehicles to supplement their own resources. When used effectively and appropriately, asset seizure and forfeiture laws can recoup criminal profits that deter criminal activity and compensate victims of crime."

“On Aug. 1, 2017, the United States Senate adopted the ‘National Whistleblower Appreciation Day’ resolution by unanimous consent. This resolution, which the Senate has passed every year since it was first introduced by Sen. Charles Grassley (R-Iowa) in 2013, commemorates the enactment of America’s first whistleblower law. The history behind this resolution is remarkable. It marks one of the first real tests of American democracy and how those in power would treat whistleblowers who exposed wrongdoing within the revolutionary government itself,” wrote Stephen Kohn in an op-ed for The Hill.   “In February 1777, ten sailors and marines aboard the ship Warren, stationed in Providence harbor, signed a petition protesting the actions of the first commodore of the United States Navy. They accused their commander of gross misconduct, mistreating prisoners of war and war profiteering. One of the ten whistleblowers, Captain of the Marines John Grannis, jumped ship (without permission) and presented the whistleblowers’ petition to the Continental Congress. The Founding Fathers were tested. How would the new revolutionary government treat dissent? How would they judge United States citizens raising serious allegations aimed at a high-ranking official appointed by the Congress itself?”  Read more about the history of whistleblower protection below. Senator Grassley is chairman and a co-founder of the 12-member bipartisan Senate Whistleblower Protection Caucus.

President Trump signed into law the bipartisan Over-the-Counter Hearing Aid Act. Senator Grassley voted for landmark tax reform legislation, which passed the United States Senate this morning. It will be voted on by the House of Representatives later today before going to the President for his signature this afternoon. Senator Grassley successfully included taxpayer rights and corporate accountability measures in the tax reform legislation, and also helped protect the wind energy production tax credit, which he originally authored, and the student loan interest deduction.   “This historic legislation makes good on a promise to deliver tax relief to Americans from every walk of life and income level. Its passage is good news for working families, U.S. jobs and industry and an economy that was stagnant for far too long. It will let Iowans keep more of their own money, so they can choose how best to spend what they’ve earned. Wages will also grow and jobs will return to our shores as a result of making American industry and workers more globally competitive,” Senator Grassley said.  “There have been some misconceptions about what this legislation does, which ideological opponents of lower taxes have helped sow. Iowans are understandably paying close attention to how they will be impacted. Iowans should rest assured they will begin seeing more in their take home pay almost immediately, and that will continue for years to come. This tax reform legislation lowers rates on every income level, and the progressivity of the tax code is maintained, ensuring that Iowans of all stripes will share the benefits of tax reform, and no one group is treated unfairly.
